感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

香港國際關係的啟蒙教育。逃犯條例修訂已經實際上取消了，不要再用「反送中」之類做標語，免得外國人說反對運動已經成功，你們來做什麼？

要講的，是「保衛香港憲法」，將基本法的憲法地位講給大眾及國際知道，講得多就成事。
向領事館請願，向國際報紙登意見廣告，是「敦促國際社會保護香港獨立司法管轄權」或簡單說「保護香港自治」，不是「反送中」。「反送中」已經out咗，因為已經成功爭取。

講「憲法」、講「自治」，多向國際宣傳，香港就變成實然的主權國家，知道中共是侵略香港的constituton和autonomy。明未？

quote.msg:
感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

想問下financial times 版本個個係咪不變？
我覺得呢份都寫得超好：



Dear FT Readers,

A white terror has descended upon Hong Kong. Our government has pushed a bill that would extradite “fugitives” in Hong Kong - citizens, foreigners and tourists alike - to China for alleged crimes. The G20 summit this Friday brings a truce; once it is over, our future is doomed, unless you help us now.

We feared these arbitrary “deportations”. We shouted, to deaf ears. Lawyers, chambers of commerce, and millions of us were all rubbished by chief executive Carrie Lam. Without a choice, we surrounded the legislature peacefully. A violent crackdown followed. Defenceless protesters and journalists were beaten, tear gassed, and even headshot. The injured were arrested in hospitals and charged for “rioting”.

This mini-Tiananmen did not move Lam. The EU condemned the Bill; Amnesty International found the police excessive; US senators mulled sanctions. Nevertheless, Lam declined to withdraw the bill. The bill is on hold now, but more arrests and crackdown may come, as the Trump-Xi meeting ends and attention shifts. Our people are at risk of miscarriage of justice. If Lam truly wants to restore our trust, she just needs to meet our three humble demands:

Release of peaceful protesters;
Independent investigation into police brutality;
Complete withdrawal of the bill.
Sadly, she won’t listen to us. We now need your support: get our voices heard at your governments and consulates; let freedom prevail at the upcoming G20 summit and beyond. We can be saved, if you act now.

Yours truly,

Hong Kong Citizens, Vanguards of Freedom

———

呢個超好
想問下financial times 版本個個係咪不變？
我覺得呢份都寫得超好：



Dear FT Readers,

A white terror has descended upon Hong Kong. Our government has pushed a bill that would extradite “fugitives” in Hong Kong - citizens, foreigners and tourists alike - to China for alleged crimes. The G20 summit this Friday brings a truce; once it is over, our future is doomed, unless you help us now.

We feared these arbitrary “deportations”. We shouted, to deaf ears. Lawyers, chambers of commerce, and millions of us were all rubbished by chief executive Carrie Lam. Without a choice, we surrounded the legislature peacefully. A violent crackdown followed. Defenceless protesters and journalists were beaten, tear gassed, and even headshot. The injured were arrested in hospitals and charged for “rioting”.

This mini-Tiananmen did not move Lam. The EU condemned the Bill; Amnesty International found the police excessive; US senators mulled sanctions. Nevertheless, Lam declined to withdraw the bill. The bill is on hold now, but more arrests and crackdown may come, as the Trump-Xi meeting ends and attention shifts. Our people are at risk of miscarriage of justice. If Lam truly wants to restore our trust, she just needs to meet our three humble demands:

Release of peaceful protesters;
Independent investigation into police brutality;
Complete withdrawal of the bill.
Sadly, she won’t listen to us. We now need your support: get our voices heard at your governments and consulates; let freedom prevail at the upcoming G20 summit and beyond. We can be saved, if you act now.

Yours truly,

Hong Kong Citizens, Vanguards of Freedom

———

我覺得呢份都寫得超好：



Dear FT Readers,

A white terror has descended upon Hong Kong. Our government has pushed a bill that would extradite “fugitives” in Hong Kong - citizens, foreigners and tourists alike - to China for alleged crimes. The G20 summit this Friday brings a truce; once it is over, our future is doomed, unless you help us now.

We feared these arbitrary “deportations”. We shouted, to deaf ears. Lawyers, chambers of commerce, and millions of us were all rubbished by chief executive Carrie Lam. Without a choice, we surrounded the legislature peacefully. A violent crackdown followed. Defenceless protesters and journalists were beaten, tear gassed, and even headshot. The injured were arrested in hospitals and charged for “rioting”.

This mini-Tiananmen did not move Lam. The EU condemned the Bill; Amnesty International found the police excessive; US senators mulled sanctions. Nevertheless, Lam declined to withdraw the bill. The bill is on hold now, but more arrests and crackdown may come, as the Trump-Xi meeting ends and attention shifts. Our people are at risk of miscarriage of justice. If Lam truly wants to restore our trust, she just needs to meet our three humble demands:

Release of peaceful protesters;
Independent investigation into police brutality;
Complete withdrawal of the bill.
Sadly, she won’t listen to us. We now need your support: get our voices heard at your governments and consulates; let freedom prevail at the upcoming G20 summit and beyond. We can be saved, if you act now.

Yours truly,

Hong Kong Citizens, Vanguards of Freedom

———

Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters". It showed that the Hong Kong government defied peaceful protesters’ appeals and the police had abused their power, which induced two million of us took to the streets on June 16 to expressed our demands.

我覺得呢份都寫得超好：



Dear FT Readers,

A white terror has descended upon Hong Kong. Our government has pushed a bill that would extradite “fugitives” in Hong Kong - citizens, foreigners and tourists alike - to China for alleged crimes. The G20 summit this Friday brings a truce; once it is over, our future is doomed, unless you help us now.

We feared these arbitrary “deportations”. We shouted, to deaf ears. Lawyers, chambers of commerce, and millions of us were all rubbished by chief executive Carrie Lam. Without a choice, we surrounded the legislature peacefully. A violent crackdown followed. Defenceless protesters and journalists were beaten, tear gassed, and even headshot. The injured were arrested in hospitals and charged for “rioting”.

This mini-Tiananmen did not move Lam. The EU condemned the Bill; Amnesty International found the police excessive; US senators mulled sanctions. Nevertheless, Lam declined to withdraw the bill. The bill is on hold now, but more arrests and crackdown may come, as the Trump-Xi meeting ends and attention shifts. Our people are at risk of miscarriage of justice. If Lam truly wants to restore our trust, she just needs to meet our three humble demands:

Release of peaceful protesters;
Independent investigation into police brutality;
Complete withdrawal of the bill.
Sadly, she won’t listen to us. We now need your support: get our voices heard at your governments and consulates; let freedom prevail at the upcoming G20 summit and beyond. We can be saved, if you act now.

Yours truly,

Hong Kong Citizens, Vanguards of Freedom

———

最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

I would suggest the below amendment:

“We urge our government to agree to HongKongers three reasonable requests:”

感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

Dear readers of The New York Times,

因為個publication 既全名係 ‘The New York Times’, 唔係’New York Times’。

我哋嘅水平始終要高過DoJ鄭若驊，有啲嘢係要咬文嚼字。

今次係香港人歷史性時刻，背負好多期望

一定唔可以柒

樓主有咩要幫手出聲啦，咁多勁人實幫到你

how about this? we need strong emotional appeal, not a boring factual description.


Dear New York,

We are on the verge of being assimilated to China by our own Government in Hong Kong.

Our population is a mere 7 million. Last Sunday, 2 million of us marched on the street calling for a halt of our Government's effort of trying to legitimise extradition from Hong Kong to China, ironically, in exchange for ignorance from the Government backed by China and violence from the Police. Many of us were injured and one committed suicide to make himself heard.

Strong propaganda machines from the pro-establishment camps backed by China have been activated to divert public views. We could not to be silenced. We cwould not give away any more of our freedoms and civil rights would be eroded. We have no alternative but to appeal to you on this occasion of the G20 summit where a meeting between President Trump and President Xi will be held.

Feel us and help deliver our concerns and demands to your legislators and governments.

Stand by us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule also on social media. #SaveHongKong #FreeHongKong #WeAreOneHongKong

Hong Kong is NOT China.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers




[Smaller font]

Some background on Hong Kong politics and the extradition bill.

Under the current political regime, only half of our Legislative Councillors are directly elected by the people. Our Chief Executive is elected by an 1200-people electoral committee, a majority of them manipulated by China.

We were promised democracy by having our Legislative Council and Chief Executive elected via universal suffrage gradually in our de facto constitution, the Basic Law, which the Chinese Government possesses the right of interpretation. It has been 22 years since handed over from Britain to China. Those seem like empty promises to us.

These aside, in 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that legitimises the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for ruling by (their) law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Businessmen, bankers, ordinary Hongkongers and even tourists could be arrested in Hong Kong and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes if not fabricated accusations. Should the bill be passed, Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

In a conflict, later coined as "riot" by the Government, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Many peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill;
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors; and
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality;

We shall continue to fight for our rights, freedoms and democracy, and surmount all difficulties ahead. Stay with us.

[website/fb page with the full version of what happened]

quote.msg:
感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

Hongkongers shall never surrender.

The totalitarian government of China manifests its evilness in the proposal of the Extradition Law in Hong Kong, a law that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers the safety of all foreigners who chance to travel or stay in this land of freedom. The government refused to listen to the voice of 2 million of protesters, and they even sent the Hong Kong Police Force to terrorize the people.

We are lovers of freedom living in a place called Hong Kong that has fallen into the dark hand of totalitarianism since 1997. Still we have never forgotten the true worth of freedom, democracy and human rights. They never succeeded in convincing us otherwise.

We will stand firm to fight for our autonomy. We will stand firm to fight for our democracy. And we will resist totalitarianism in the name of freedom. Hongkongers shall never surrender.

The Extradition Law must be completely withdrawn, and, in addition, the autonomy of Hong Kong must be guaranteed with the introduction of true Universal Suffrage in the Legislative Council and thereafter the Chief Executive. Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberateHK

Hongkongers shall never surrender

The totalitarian government of China manifests its evilness in the proposal of the Extradition Law in Hong Kong, a law that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers the safety of all foreigners who chance to travel or stay in this land of freedom. The government refused to listen to the voice of 2 million of protesters, and they even sent the Hong Kong Police Force to terrorize the people.

We are lovers of freedom living in Hong Kong which has fallen into the dark hand of totalitarianism since 1997. Still we have never once forgotten the true worth of freedom, democracy and human rights. They never succeeded in convincing us otherwise.

We will stand firm to fight for our autonomy. We will stand firm to fight for our democracy. And we will resist totalitarianism in the name of freedom. Hongkongers shall never surrender.

The proposal of the Extradition Law must be completely withdrawn, and in addition, the autonomy of Hong Kong must be guaranteed with the introduction of Universal Suffrage in the election of the Legislative Council and thereafter the Chief Executive. Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberateHK #weshallneversurrender

The government refused to listen to the voice of 2 million of protesters, and they even sent the Hong Kong Police Force to terrorize the people.

We are lovers of freedom living in Hong Kong which has fallen into the dark hand of totalitarianism since 1997. Still we have never once forgotten the true worth of freedom, democracy and human rights. They never succeeded in convincing us otherwise.

We will stand firm to fight for our autonomy. We will stand firm to fight for our democracy. And we will resist totalitarianism in the name of freedom. Hongkongers shall never surrender.

The proposal of the Extradition Law must be completely withdrawn, and in addition, the autonomy of Hong Kong must be guaranteed with the introduction of Universal Suffrage in the election of the Legislative Council and thereafter the Chief Executive. Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberateHK #weshallneversurrender

replies.msg:
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the 2 million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to ally with us, demanding the preservation of Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under the Chinese Government.

We humbly thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

The totalitarian government of China manifests its evilness in the proposal of the Extradition Law in Hong Kong, a law that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers all foreigners who chance to travel or stay in this land of freedom. Hongkongers shall never surrender. We will stand firm to fight for our autonomy. We will stand firm to fight for our democracy. And we will resist totalitarianism in the name of freedom.

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

replies.msg:
https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2869569203084907&id=189060481135806
楊衛隆

G20一戰定江山
六月底的G20峰會快要舉行，習包子急到餓狗搶屎，北韓也親身走一次，美國死對頭塔里班也官式見面。中共叫外國勢力不要插手香港事務，叫外國傳媒不要報導香港示威。港共也是餓狗搶屎，616示威不鎮壓不清場，林賤站出來假道歉; 學生要圍政總，政總當日休息一天，避其風頭。香港人不滿國歌法，立即暫停二讀。似乎，任何能夠產生磨擦的事情都避之則吉。
到底發生甚麼事? G20會有甚麼事情發生?
美國人的G20計劃十分簡單直接，當勞侵在G20峰會聯合所有國家一齊支持美國的香港人權法，制裁侵犯香港人權的中港官員，並且不承認小圈子特首選舉結果。茶友不是要林鄭下台，是要一國兩制下台。只要美國國會通過香港人權法，支持香港自治，所有國家一齊不承認小圈子選舉特首，一國兩制名實俱亡。香港普選有國際監察，不能造假。香港立法會也會去掉功能組別。
茶友的武器是香港貿易優惠和制裁中港員。中英聯合聲明給香港人的自治權，中共一定要尊重，否則，香港將失去貿易優惠，中共也失去唯一對外金融貿易窗口。
當勞侵若果逐一遊說其他國家支持香港自治，十分困難而且花時間。很多國家不敢貿然對付中共。可是，G20峰會有朋輩壓力，加拿大、英國、德國、法國、日本和南韓等國家必然積極支持美國。不少國家在G20有求於西方國家，當然不敢當眾拒絕支持美國聯盟。當十多個國家支持美國的時候，沒有國家會站到中共那邊去。習大大當然明白自己的處境。要是小圈子選舉被國際社會認定非法，中共將失去香港控制權，香港會得到真正自治。香港有了自治又有美國為首的美國聯盟監察香港自治和人權，一國兩制不復存在。
香港要重回英聯邦，難比登天。但是，香港加入「美聯邦」易如反掌，撐到G20就可以。香港人不要錯過G20黃金機會。
飯民天天在街上討捐款，討選票。香港人給飯民多少錢? 給飯民多少選票? 結果得到甚麼?
飯民的「血債票償」其實是「賣港求票」，千萬不要等到七一才動手。到了七一，G20危機過去，習帝和林賤會大開殺戒，清算所有人。很快，很多學生會被五花大綁押到咁至驚廣場公開批鬥，酷刑致死。每星期都有批鬥大會，日日殺人，滿街紅衛兵。
非常老實，香港無法用自己的力量抗衡中共。不要天真到以為616示威200萬人上街令到中共和港共主場軟化。612示威百萬人上街可以血腥鎮壓，200萬人上街一樣可以照樣開槍，而且真槍實彈。香港不投向習帝就要投向美帝，只能選一個。不選美帝就是選習帝。選習帝是死路一條。林賤肯定不會是最殘酷的小圈子選舉特首，遲早會出現血魔特首。
香港人的前途由香港人決定，決定的時間就在這幾天，好自為之。

replies.msg: 幫推

個人意見

1) 其實可以講d大方向加少少煽情, 要代表到一般市民, 唔使用d咁辛辣批判既字眼

2) 唔使講太多反送中, 引渡條例好多國家都有, 外國人未必清楚成件事, 甚至黑警都唔使點講, 要有明確主題, 講香港民主自由被逼害

3) 可以以香港回歸開始, 中國承諾一國兩制, 50年不變, 但依家一半都未過, 中國就違反承諾, 用修法, 釋法呢d手段干預香港自主權

4) 强調香港人一直以來政治冷漠, 從來無要求更多, 只係希望保有應有既權利先一次又一次上街遊行甚至更激進行動

5) 中國一直無新聞同言論自由, 如果今次香港人唔發聲, 恐怕自此以後國際上再無香港既聲音

6) 大字用we will not surrender 幾好, 夠震撼

（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

quote.msg:
感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

－強調香港人係自由世界一份子 雖然落左係極權既超級大國手中二十年 仍然熱愛自由 民主 人權
－再講下香港人有幾團結同對抗暴政既決心 毫不退縮
－簡短有力三段就夠
－plead/beg/save 個啲字唔建議用 太卑微 亦都令人覺得大把陷入緊戰亂既國家慘撚過你
亦都唔建議用太arrogant 既字眼 好似香港人救世界
－要不亢不卑 希望自由世界人民join us in the fight against totalitarianism[/quote]其實依個point都好多人同意，不如試下改改佢
我地都知道文宣好辛苦，但趁有國際關注個陣，不妨講闊啲、長遠啲。
－淨係反送中真係太短視。其實難得國際關注,寫多個point, 爭取民主/普選.留個大方向, 會唔會比較好? 等國際間可以持續關注香港形勢,形成一股真正外援力量.真心希望篇文可以更進取, 更激昂

4）排版出現問題，唔好用英文對齊

4）加Hashtag
－ #LiberateHK
－用d無左HK呢兩個字ge hastag
（ 更可以推上大舞台 如果其他受抑壓嘅事 都可以用同一個Tag 影響可以更深遠 e.g. 蘇丹內亂＞可能引發到metoo movement）

拝啓
この新聞紙をお読みになるあなたへ

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

replies.msg:
睇下呢個o唔ok

-----------------------------

The Chinese government once again showed its true colors to the world through the proposal of the Extradition Law Amendment Bill in Hong Kong, a bill that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers all foreigners residing, visiting, or even merely transiting through this bastion of freedom and liberty. [1]

Despite millions of protesters turning out in two consecutive Sundays, and a large-scale peaceful gathering that turned violent when the Hong Kong Police Force unleashed disproportionate force on peaceful protesters, with various well-documented instances of police brutality:

1) riot police chucking tear gas grenades right at a local politician; [2]
2) shooting tear gas canisters in the middle of a cornered and panicking crowd (which almost turned into Hillsborough 2.0) [3];
3) riot police spraying an unarmed and injured man in the face with pepper spray;
4) threatening to shoot journalists; [4]

Even now, numerous protesters were unjustly arrested, with many more suffering from various degrees of injury, some of whom were too scared to go to the hospital for fear of having their personal particulars leaked to the Police unconstitutionally. [5]

The situation has since simmered down to an uneasy stalemate, with the Hong Kong SAR government (and perhaps their true masters in Beijing) steadfastly refusing our demands to i) completely withdraw the amendment bill, ii) drop all charges against the arrested protesters, and iii) promising that there will be no repercussions to all who participated in the 12th June protest outside the government headquarters. More protests have been planned in the lead-up to the G20 summit in Osaka, and enterprising netizens have even purchased ads on major newspapers around the world.

We pray that our efforts would eventually bear fruit, but even if by some miracle that the government does accede to our demands, it will not end there. The SAR government (and again, their masters in Beijing) will retaliate against this slap in their face with even more draconian measures like disqualifying lawfully elected legislators with ridiculous interpretations of the Hong Kong Basic Law (pretty much our Constitution) and digging up outdated precedents to give out harsh prison sentences to protesters [6].

Our beautiful city, our Pearl of the Orient, our Fragrant Harbor, edges ever closer to the dark valley of totalitarianism since 1997.

But we will never give up without a fight.

We will not go quietly into the night.

For better or worse, our years under British rule taught us the true worth of freedom and liberty, and the importance of a functional democracy (or at least, we’ve seen how badly can things get without one).

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberteHongKong
#FreeHongKong
#HongkongersAssemble
#HongKongForever

[1] “freedom” 同埋 “liberty” 可以二選一或者兩個用晒
[2] 即係胡志偉嗰單 – 民主國家仆街極都冇聽過警察夠膽打議員
[3] 講到中信差D變希斯堡2.0應該會對外國球迷幾有用
[4] 數住4單先，其他例子等有人問/challenge既時候再攞出黎
[5] 病人私隱呢個point應該好好講
[6] 即係梁天琦嗰單
背景可以參考下呢個

The situation has since simmered down to an uneasy stalemate, with the Hong Kong SAR government (and perhaps their true masters in Beijing) steadfastly refusing our demands to i) completely withdraw the amendment bill, ii) drop all charges against the arrested protesters, and iii) promising that there will be no repercussions to all who participated in the 12th June protest outside the government headquarters. More protests have been planned in the lead-up to the G20 summit in Osaka, and enterprising netizens have even purchased ads on major newspapers around the world.

We pray that our efforts would eventually bear fruit, but even if by some miracle that the government does accede to our demands, it will not end there. The SAR government (and again, their masters in Beijing) will retaliate against this slap in their face with even more draconian measures like disqualifying lawfully elected legislators with ridiculous interpretations of the Hong Kong Basic Law (pretty much our Constitution) and digging up outdated precedents to give out harsh prison sentences to protesters [6].

Our beautiful city, our Pearl of the Orient, our Fragrant Harbor, edges ever closer to the dark valley of totalitarianism since 1997.

But we will never give up without a fight.

We will not go quietly into the night.

For better or worse, our years under British rule taught us the true worth of freedom and liberty, and the importance of a functional democracy (or at least, we’ve seen how badly can things get without one).

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberteHongKong
#FreeHongKong
#HongkongersAssemble
#HongKongForever

[1] “freedom” 同埋 “liberty” 可以二選一或者兩個用晒
[2] 即係胡志偉嗰單 – 民主國家仆街極都冇聽過警察夠膽打議員
[3] 講到中信差D變希斯堡2.0應該會對外國球迷幾有用
[4] 數住4單先，其他例子等有人問/challenge既時候再攞出黎
[5] 病人私隱呢個point應該好好講
[6] 即係梁天琦嗰單

_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

この新聞紙をお読みになるあなたへ

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

代post:

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

如果認同以上建議，煩請代為轉載至連登。

（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

代post:

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

如果認同以上建議，煩請代為轉載至連登。

拝啓
この新聞紙をお読みになるあなたへ

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

https://www.facebook.com/283281381770696/posts/2162584980506984?sfns=mo

代post:

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

如果認同以上建議，煩請代為轉載至連登。

拝啓
この新聞紙をお読みになるあなたへ

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

代post:

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

睇下呢個o唔ok

-----------------------------

The Chinese government once again showed its true colors to the world through the proposal of the Extradition Law Amendment Bill in Hong Kong, a bill that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers all foreigners residing, visiting, or even merely transiting through this bastion of freedom and liberty. [1]

Despite millions of protesters turning out in two consecutive Sundays, and a large-scale peaceful gathering that turned violent when the Hong Kong Police Force unleashed disproportionate force on peaceful protesters, with various well-documented instances of police brutality:

1) riot police chucking tear gas grenades right at a local politician; [2]
2) shooting tear gas canisters in the middle of a cornered and panicking crowd (which almost turned into Hillsborough 2.0) [3];
3) riot police spraying an unarmed and injured man in the face with pepper spray;
4) threatening to shoot journalists; [4]

Even now, numerous protesters were unjustly arrested, with many more suffering from various degrees of injury, some of whom were too scared to go to the hospital for fear of having their personal particulars leaked to the Police unconstitutionally. [5]

The situation has since simmered down to an uneasy stalemate, with the Hong Kong SAR government (and perhaps their true masters in Beijing) steadfastly refusing our demands to i) completely withdraw the amendment bill, ii) drop all charges against the arrested protesters, and iii) promising that there will be no repercussions to all who participated in the 12th June protest outside the government headquarters. More protests have been planned in the lead-up to the G20 summit in Osaka, and enterprising netizens have even purchased ads on major newspapers around the world.

We pray that our efforts would eventually bear fruit, but even if by some miracle that the government does accede to our demands, it will not end there. The SAR government (and again, their masters in Beijing) will retaliate against this slap in their face with even more draconian measures like disqualifying lawfully elected legislators with ridiculous interpretations of the Hong Kong Basic Law (pretty much our Constitution) and digging up outdated precedents to give out harsh prison sentences to protesters [6].

Our beautiful city, our Pearl of the Orient, our Fragrant Harbor, edges ever closer to the dark valley of totalitarianism since 1997.

But we will never give up without a fight.

We will not go quietly into the night.

For better or worse, our years under British rule taught us the true worth of freedom and liberty, and the importance of a functional democracy (or at least, we’ve seen how badly can things get without one).

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberteHongKong
#FreeHongKong
#HongkongersAssemble
#HongKongForever

[1] “freedom” 同埋 “liberty” 可以二選一或者兩個用晒

感謝各個連登仔女，各界人士大力支持及相助！！
最後我地條team同我要攬炒巴團隊一齊改好以下呢個draft，
6月28日嘅New York Times有全頁ad，到時見！！！
（好多外國報紙唔會做頭版，我地盡咗力。但係我地而家都繼續同其他報紙有聯絡，日、英、澳、法、德、台都有努力準備緊，希望有好消息！唔好意思因為一直好忙所以無覆大家留言，但係我地有巴絲有留意住架！感謝大家！！！）


_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers

replies.msg:
小小意見

第二段嗰度可唔可以改成咁：

過去数年、中国政府は香港公民の自由と権利を頻りに押しかけた。選挙を通して選んだ議員達、違う政見を持ちだけで、一方的に失格と判断さることがあり。今回には、香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国と香港の裁判制度は根本的の違いがあり、容疑者の弁護権利は保障されないという恐れがあり。従って、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される批判的な意見が多い。

利申：2年前日文N2
感激

拝啓
この新聞紙をお読みになるあなたへ

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

過去数年、中国政府は香港公民の自由と権利を頻りに押しかけた。選挙を通して選んだ議員達、違う政見を持ちだけで、一方的に失格と判断さることがあり。今回には、香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国と香港の裁判制度は根本的の違いがあり、容疑者の弁護権利は保障されないという恐れがあり。従って、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される批判的な意見が多い。

轉載自fb oage逆嘶亭，相當合理，樓主見到的話麻煩參考一下

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

如果認同以上建議，煩請代為轉載至連登。
（全日冇上連登，一post至知原來已經截稿）

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港にあける二百万人を集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。今、香港人は自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力をお借りていただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。中国は刑事事件における裁判有罪率99.9%にもかかわらず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあります。

また、香港への日本旅行客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せる可能性があります。

さらに、デモの参加者が警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾などの必要以上の鎮圧武器を受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えています：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちの釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港現在起きていることを周りの親友に知らせてください。
あなたの関心と拡散する行動だけで、香港の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝します。

私たちは先週の日曜日（6月16日）香港における二百万人が集まったデモに関心を持っておるグループでございます。現在、香港人は中国政府のプレッシャーで自由を失う恐怖に囲まれています。ここで、ぜひ皆様のお力を貸していただき、香港の自由を取り戻したく存じます。

香港政府は刑事事件の「容疑者」を香港から中国本土へ引き渡せるようにする「逃亡犯条例」改正案を提出しました。世界に通用されている無罪推定原則に属さない中国の刑事裁判の有罪率は99.9%であること、そもそも疑問される点があるのみならず、この 「逃亡犯条例」 によって、香港司法の独立性と「一国二制度」がさらに中国政府に侵食される恐れがあると思われています。

又、「逃亡犯条例」 により、香港への日本人観光客や香港在住日本人が万が一、香港で法律に違反する場合、中国へ引き渡せることは可能になります。

尚、６月１２日に、デモの参加者が香港警察から催涙ガスやゴム弾など、必要以上の武力鎮圧したことを受け、多くの負傷者が出ました。一部の負傷者は病院で警察に逮捕されることや、病院の看護に拒否されることなどの「白色テロ」も起きています。

現在、私たちは以下の請求を香港政府に訴えております：
1. 「逃亡犯条例」改正案の全面撤回
2. デモを「暴動」と決めつけたことの撤回
3. デモにおける逮捕者たちを無条件で釈放

香港を愛している方、香港にお尋ねになったことがある方、香港に興味を持っていらっしゃる方、
ぜひ香港が現在起きていることを周りの親友にお知らせ頂けますと幸いでございます。
あなたの関心及びニュースを拡散することのみ、香港にいる我々の力になります。

香港を応援するあなたに、心の底から感謝申し上げます。

------------------------------

The Chinese government once again showed its true colors to the world through the proposal of the Extradition Law Amendment Bill in Hong Kong, a bill that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers all foreigners residing, visiting, or even merely transiting through this bastion of freedom and liberty. [1]

Despite millions of protesters turning out in two consecutive Sundays, and a large-scale peaceful gathering that turned violent when the Hong Kong Police Force unleashed disproportionate force on peaceful protesters, with various well-documented instances of police brutality:

1) riot police chucking tear gas grenades right at a local politician; [2]
2) shooting tear gas canisters in the middle of a cornered and panicking crowd (which almost turned into Hillsborough 2.0) [3];
3) riot police spraying an unarmed and injured man in the face with pepper spray;
4) threatening to shoot journalists; [4]

Even now, numerous protesters were unjustly arrested, with many more suffering from various degrees of injury, some of whom were too scared to go to the hospital for fear of having their personal particulars leaked to the Police unconstitutionally. [5]

The situation has since simmered down to an uneasy stalemate, with the Hong Kong SAR government (and perhaps their true masters in Beijing) steadfastly refusing our demands to i) completely withdraw the amendment bill, ii) drop all charges against the arrested protesters, and iii) promising that there will be no repercussions to all who participated in the 12th June protest outside the government headquarters. More protests have been planned in the lead-up to the G20 summit in Osaka, and enterprising netizens have even purchased ads on major newspapers around the world.

We pray that our efforts would eventually bear fruit, but even if by some miracle that the government does accede to our demands, it will not end there. The SAR government (and again, their masters in Beijing) will retaliate against this slap in their face with even more draconian measures like disqualifying lawfully elected legislators with ridiculous interpretations of the Hong Kong Basic Law (pretty much our Constitution) and digging up outdated precedents to give out harsh prison sentences to protesters [6].

Our beautiful city, our Pearl of the Orient, our Fragrant Harbor, edges ever closer to the dark valley of totalitarianism since 1997.

But we will never give up without a fight.

We will not go quietly into the night.

For better or worse, our years under British rule taught us the true worth of freedom and liberty, and the importance of a functional democracy (or at least, we’ve seen how badly can things get without one).

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberteHongKong
#FreeHongKong
#HongkongersAssemble
#HongKongForever

三黎義士有血有肉vs黑警殘暴冷血
四黎對我地有好大象徵意義－pp個烈士
但要搵返個授權

3）自由民主等核心價值為主，反送中為次
－唔好長篇大論講反送中 只攞嚟做一個例子反映共產主義滲透 （勾起返鬼對冷戰嘅回憶）再講少少警察暴行 引發人地同情心
－強調香港人係自由世界一份子 雖然落左係極權既超級大國手中二十年 仍然熱愛自由 民主 人權
－再講下香港人有幾團結同對抗暴政既決心 毫不退縮

亦都唔建議用太arrogant 既字眼 好似香港人救世界

轉載自fb oage逆嘶亭，相當合理，樓主見到的話麻煩參考一下

關於眾籌登報post。

草稿首段表明身分，選用「defend our sovereignty」，極為可取。捍衛主權，係香港屢次抗爭都未出現過嘅用語，史無前例，氣勢直迫中共宣傳機器至愛嘅五四口號——「外爭主權，內除國賊」。眾所周知，主權所指，並非單單係《基本法》所保證嘅治權，而係指國家對其管轄範圍內嘅政務擁有至高無上嘅完整主權，免受任何外力干預，所謂外力，明顯指涉中共，否則亦毋須登去美國大報。

而第二至第四段，文字亦有力點出香港優於中國，劃清界線，直擊要害。「notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law」，係針對中國依法治國嘅指控，強調中國嘅惡名昭彰，等同拉近香港同自由陣營嘅距離，亦顯示出香港尊重英治遺產嘅決心。特意為警察暴行闢出一段詳加描述，亦有助國際社會了解港共政府如何縱容警隊，結合日前廣泛流傳嘅抗爭靚相，外界就可以理解到香港問題有幾嚴峻。

然而，野心太大，又想講賺錢，又想講人權，或者會令焦點模糊。「Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers」呢四種人的確會受影響，但bankers同businessmen性質相似，點解要特別提及？或者刪去bankers，換上journalists，就更有助表達人人都有危險嘅意思。

更加值得商榷嘅係，「Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone」一句，其實對自由陣營影響並唔切身，而承接上句「trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations」嘅話，更理想而又更能打動讀者嘅，應該係言論自由以至人身理由受到威脅，香港距離民主自由前所未有咁遠。講錢，雖然好有Hongkongness，但香港做唔到自由港而新加坡做到，其實西方係唔介意。假如寫成「, which is greatly devastating the liberal environment of Hong Kong and shrinking people’s power of free speech and expression of ideas.」，整體效果大概會更佳。

如果認同以上建議，煩請代為轉載至連登。
（全日冇上連登，一post至知原來已經截稿）
推

------------------------------

The Chinese government once again showed its true colors to the world through the proposal of the Extradition Law Amendment Bill in Hong Kong, a bill that not only destroys the autonomy of Hong Kong, but also endangers all foreigners residing, visiting, or even merely transiting through this bastion of freedom and liberty. [1]

Despite millions of protesters turning out in two consecutive Sundays, and a large-scale peaceful gathering that turned violent when the Hong Kong Police Force unleashed disproportionate force on peaceful protesters, with various well-documented instances of police brutality:

1) riot police chucking tear gas grenades right at a local politician; [2]
2) shooting tear gas canisters in the middle of a cornered and panicking crowd (which almost turned into Hillsborough 2.0) [3];
3) riot police spraying an unarmed and injured man in the face with pepper spray;
4) threatening to shoot journalists; [4]

Even now, numerous protesters were unjustly arrested, with many more suffering from various degrees of injury, some of whom were too scared to go to the hospital for fear of having their personal particulars leaked to the Police unconstitutionally. [5]

The situation has since simmered down to an uneasy stalemate, with the Hong Kong SAR government (and perhaps their true masters in Beijing) steadfastly refusing our demands to i) completely withdraw the amendment bill, ii) drop all charges against the arrested protesters, and iii) promising that there will be no repercussions to all who participated in the 12th June protest outside the government headquarters. More protests have been planned in the lead-up to the G20 summit in Osaka, and enterprising netizens have even purchased ads on major newspapers around the world.

We pray that our efforts would eventually bear fruit, but even if by some miracle that the government does accede to our demands, it will not end there. The SAR government (and again, their masters in Beijing) will retaliate against this slap in their face with even more draconian measures like disqualifying lawfully elected legislators with ridiculous interpretations of the Hong Kong Basic Law (pretty much our Constitution) and digging up outdated precedents to give out harsh prison sentences to protesters [6].

Our beautiful city, our Pearl of the Orient, our Fragrant Harbor, edges ever closer to the dark valley of totalitarianism since 1997.

But we will never give up without a fight.

We will not go quietly into the night.

For better or worse, our years under British rule taught us the true worth of freedom and liberty, and the importance of a functional democracy (or at least, we’ve seen how badly can things get without one).

Join us in the fight against totalitarianism by delivering our concerns and demands to your governments in view of the upcoming G20 summit.

#LiberteHongKong
#FreeHongKong
#HongkongersAssemble
#HongKongForever

[1] “freedom” 同埋 “liberty” 可以二選一或者兩個用晒
[2] 即係胡志偉嗰單 – 民主國家仆街極都冇聽過警察夠膽打議員
[3] 講到中信差D變希斯堡2.0應該會對外國球迷幾有用
[4] 數住4單先，其他例子等有人問/challenge既時候再攞出黎
[5] 病人私隱呢個point應該好好講
[6] 即係梁天琦嗰單

_________________________________________________________________________
Dear New York Times Readers,

We are a group of concerned citizens who have been among the two million protesters marching on the streets of Hong Kong. This is our sincere plea for your help to defend our sovereignty and freedoms. Here is why you should care.

In 2019, the Hong Kong SAR Government proposed a bill that would allow the extradition of alleged “fugitives” from Hong Kong to China, a country that is notorious for its disrespect for the rule of law. The judicial system in China has a conviction rate of 99.9%, and prisoners are known to have suffered from severe violations of human rights.

Bankers, businessmen, tourists, and even ordinary Hongkongers could be arrested and sent to China for trials of alleged crimes and fabricated accusations. Hong Kong will cease to be a free economic zone, which has long served the world’s most prominent businesses.

This is why two million of us took to the streets. We were unarmed. We had only helmets, umbrellas and plastic wrap. In return, the police suppressed us by unleashing 150 tear gas canisters shot in close range, aiming batons at our heads, and firing rubber bullets and bean bag rounds. Numerous peaceful protesters were unjustifiably arrested, interrogated, and stigmatized as “rioters".

Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has announced a suspension of the Extradition Bill which is NOT equivalent to withdrawal. We urge our government to agree to our three demands:

1. To completely withdraw the Extradition Bill.
2. To release all the arrested unconditionally and undertake not to prosecute any of the protestors.
3. To appoint an independent commission of inquiry to look into incidents of police brutality.

In view of the upcoming G20 summit and the meeting between Trump and Xi, we implore you to deliver our concerns and demands to your governments. We urge you to stand with us in preserving Hong Kong’s freedom and autonomy under Chinese rule.

Thank you.

Yours truly,
Hongkongers
